choices.text: The number of maternal deaths per 1000 live births
The number of maternal deaths per 100000 live births
The number of maternal deaths in women of reproductive age group
The number of maternal deaths amongst all women

questions.text: Maternal mortality ratio is defined as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The number of maternal deaths per 100000 live births

 

Maternal Mortality Ratio

 

  • Defined as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births
  • India’s MMR has improved to 103 in 2017-19, from 113 in 2016-18
  • Seven Indian states have very high maternal mortality (> 130). These are Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Bihar, Odisha and Assam
  • India has committed itself to the latest UN target for the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) for MMR at 70 per 1,00,000 live births by 2030
  • As per National Health Policy 2017, the target for MMR is 100 per 1,00,000 live births by 2020

 

Maternal Mortality Rate

 

  • The maternal mortality rate is the number of maternal deaths in a population divided by the number of women of reproductive age .

 

Other Options: Thus Options A), C) and D) do not satisfy the definition of maternal mortality ratio.

 

Educational Objective: The maternal mortality ratio is a vital indicator for evaluating the quality of healthcare services related to pregnancy and childbirth. It specifically measures the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, offering a standardized metric to assess and improve maternal health worldwide.

 

Ref: Page no 796, JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: A separate birthing area to be given to each patient to ensure privacy
Birthing in dorsal position should be encouraged
Encourage the presence of a birth companion during birth
Initiation of breastfeeding within an hour of birth

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding LaQshya?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Birthing in dorsal position should be encouraged

 

1. LaQshya

 

  • LaQshya stands for Labor room Quality Improvement Initiative
  • It is an approach to standardize care in labor rooms throughout the country
  • Launched in 2017
  • Main points
    • To reduce maternal mortality and morbidity due to labor complications
    • To improve quality of care
    • To provide Respectful Maternity Care (RMC
    • Quality Improvement Cycles (QI) are the fulcrum of LAQshya. There are 6 defined cycles and a PDCA (Plan-Do-Check-Act) methodology is used to drive and sustain change in the cycles
      • Real time partograph generation, usage of safe birth checklist and strengthening documentation practices
      • Presence of birth companion, RMC and enhancing patient satisfaction
      • Assessment, triage and timely management of complications including strengthening of referral protocols
      • Management of labor as per protocols, AMTSL and rational use of oxytocin
      • Essential and emergency newborn care, management of birth asphyxia, timely initiation of breastfeeding and Kangaroo mother care
      • Infection prevention including biomedical waste management
      • Freedom to choose a birthing position of their choice
      • Initiation of breastfeeding within 1 hour of birth

 

 

Other Options: Let's examine each option to identify the incorrect statement:

 

Options A. A separate birthing area to be given to each patient to ensure privacy: This is correct. LaQshya promotes the provision of a separate birthing area for each patient. This approach respects the privacy of the mother and is part of the effort to improve the quality of care and the overall birthing experience.

 

Options B. Birthing in dorsal position should be encouraged: This is incorrect. LaQshya does not specifically encourage birthing in the dorsal (lying on the back) position. Instead, it supports the use of comfortable and appropriate birthing positions as per the mother's preference and clinical situation. The dorsal position is often discouraged as it may not be the most beneficial for childbirth.

 

Options C. Encourage the presence of a birth companion during birth: This is correct. LaQshya encourages the presence of a birth companion during labor and delivery. This support can be beneficial for the mother's emotional and psychological well-being.

 

Options D. Initiation of breastfeeding within an hour of birth: This is correct. One of the objectives of LaQshya is to promote the initiation of breastfeeding within the first hour after birth. Early initiation of breastfeeding has significant health benefits for both the mother and the newborn.

 

Educational Objective: The LaQshya program focuses on improving the quality of care in labor rooms and maternity operation theatres, with an emphasis on respecting patient privacy, supporting mother-friendly birthing positions, encouraging the presence of a birth companion, and promoting early initiation of breastfeeding. The incorrect statement in this context is the encouragement of birthing in the dorsal position, which is not a specific recommendation of LaQshya.

 

Ref: Page 803, JB Sharmas Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Promoting Kangaroo Mother Care
Rooming in of mothers with babies
Intensified breast-feeding promotion campaign
Respectful Maternity Care

questions.text: The logo shown below is seen in your labor room. A curious patient asks you what it is about. You explain that it is regarding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intensified breast-feeding promotion campaign

 

MAA (Mother’s Absolute Affection) Program

 

  • Countrywide intensified breast-feeding promotion campaign
  • Launched on 5th August 2016

 

 

Other Options: Let us look at each option

 

Option A. Promoting Kangaroo Mother Care: Kangaroo Mother Care is a method of care of preterm infants which involves infants being carried, usually by the mother, with skin-to-skin contact. While this is an important aspect of neonatal care, the logo does not specifically represent this practice.

 

Option B. Rooming in of mothers with babies: Rooming-in refers to the practice where babies stay in the mother's room 24/7 after birth. It supports bonding and breastfeeding but is not the sole focus of the MAA program.

 

Option C. Intensified breast-feeding promotion campaign (Correct Answer): This is what the logo represents. The MAA program is an initiative by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India, to promote breastfeeding. It aims to enhance information, education, and communication regarding breastfeeding, thereby ensuring wider dissemination of its benefits and practices.

 

Option D. Respectful Maternity Care: Respectful Maternity Care is about ensuring that women are treated with dignity and respect during childbirth, which includes the right to high-quality care and a positive childbirth experience. While this is an essential component of maternal care, it is not the primary focus of the MAA program.

 

Educational Objective: The MAA program's logo symbolizes the Government of India's campaign to promote breastfeeding, aiming to improve child survival and maternal health through the advocacy and education of breastfeeding's numerous benefits. The correct answer to what the logo represents is C, an intensified breastfeeding promotion campaign

 

Ref: Page 803, JB Sharmas Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Abortion related deaths
Hemorrhage
Hypertensive disorders
Sepsis

questions.text: You are attending an international health summit as part of an Indian delegation and you are asked to prepare a 5-minute brief on maternal mortality in your country. The most common cause of maternal mortality in India is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemorrhage

 

  • Maternal deaths can be
    • Direct
    • Indirect
       
  • Direct maternal death:
    • Deaths resulting from direct complications of pregnancy, labor or puerperium
    • Most common direct causes of maternal deaths in India
      • Obstetric hemorrhage
      • Hypertensive disorders
      • Puerperal sepsis
      • Abortion related
      • Prolonged and obstructed labor
         
  • Indirect causes:
    •  Deaths from previous existing diseases that developed or worsened in pregnancy
    • These account for about 35% of all maternal deaths
    • Common cause includes -
      • Anemia
      • Heart disease
      • Thromboembolism


 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Abortion-related deaths: Unsafe abortions are a significant health concern and contribute to maternal mortality

 

Options C. Hypertensive disorders: such as pre-eclampsia and eclampsia, are critical causes of maternal mortality worldwide and also in India.

 

Options D. Sepsis: Sepsis is a severe infection that can occur during the postpartum period. It is a significant cause of maternal mortality, but not the most common one in India.

 

Educational Objective: The primary cause of maternal mortality in India is hemorrhage, particularly postpartum hemorrhage.

 

Ref: Page no 796, JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: 10
20
70
40

questions.text: As per the UNs Sustainable Development Goals, the maternal mortality ratio needs to be brought down to how much by 2030?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 70

 

Maternal Mortality Ratio

 

  • Defined as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births
  • India’s MMR has improved to 103 in 2017-19, from 113 in 2016-18
  • Seven Indian states have very high maternal mortality (> 130). These are Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Bihar, Odisha and Assam
  • India has committed itself to the latest UN target for the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) for MMR at 70 per 1,00,000 live births by 2030
  • As per National Health Policy 2017, the target for MMR is 100 per 1,00,000 live births by 2020

 

Educational Objective: The UN’s Sustainable Development Goals aim to reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births by 2030, with more developed regions setting even more ambitious targets. This emphasizes the global commitment to ensuring that women have access to high-quality maternal health care services to prevent maternal deaths.

 

Ref: Page no 796, JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Rs. 200
Rs. 400
Rs. 600
Rs. 800

questions.text: A 23y primi is brought to a district hospital by the ASHA worker for delivery. She is from a rural village in Orissa. As per the JSY scheme, how much incentive does the ASHA worker get for bringing the patient for an institutional delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rs. 600

 

Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) April 2005

 

  1. Focus is to encourage delivery at health institutions
  2. Features are
    • 100% centrally sponsored scheme
    • Integrates cash benefits to mothers and to ASHA workers

 

 

Low Performing States (LPS) are: UP, Uttarakhand, Bihar, Jharkhand, MP, Chhattisgarh, Assam, Rajasthan, Orissa, J & K

 

Educational Objective: The Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) incentivizes ASHA workers to promote institutional deliveries, with the aim of reducing maternal and neonatal mortality. The correct incentive amount for an ASHA worker bringing a patient for an institutional delivery from a rural area in Orissa is Rs. 600, though this amount may vary based on regional policies and updates to the scheme.

 

Ref: Page no 802, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Janani Suraksha Yojana
Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram
LaQshya
Vandemataram Scheme

questions.text: A private practitioner (gynecologist) is very interested in doing voluntary work for the poor. Which of the following government schemes enables her to offer her services?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vandemataram Scheme

 

Private practitioners can volunteer their services under the Vandemataram scheme

 

Vandemataram Scheme

 

  1. Voluntary scheme wherein private doctors volunteer themselves to provide safe motherhood services
  2. The enrolled doctors will display the “Vandemataram logo” at their clinic
  3. Iron, folic acid, tetanus etc. will be provided by the District Medical Officers for free distribution to beneficiaries

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Options A. Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY): JSY is a scheme aimed primarily at reducing maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional deliveries among poor pregnant women. While it is focused on institutional deliveries, it does not specifically involve private practitioners offering voluntary services.

 

Options B. Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK): JSSK entitles all pregnant women delivering in public health institutions to absolutely free and no expense delivery, including caesarean section. The initiative extends to postnatal care and treatment of sick infants up to one year of age. This program, while beneficial, is not designed for private practitioners to volunteer their services.

 

Options C. LaQshya: LaQshya is an initiative to improve the quality of care in the labor room and maternity operation theatres in public health facilities. This program focuses on the facilities themselves rather than the inclusion of private practitioners' voluntary services.

 

Educational Objective: The Vandemataram Scheme is the government initiative that enables private practitioners to offer their services voluntarily, focusing on providing free antenatal and postnatal care to pregnant women. This aligns with the interest of private practitioners like gynecologists who are keen on doing voluntary work for the poor.

 

Ref: https://main.mohfw.gov.in/sites/default/files/Chapter415.pdf

choices.text: Maternal morbidity
Maternal mortality
Perinatal morbidity
Near-miss maternal mortality

questions.text: A 30y G2 presented to the emergency with a history of seizures. On admission she is noted to be 36 weeks pregnant, and her BP is 170/100 mmHg. A diagnosis of eclampsia is made, she is administered MgSO4, and antihypertensives and labor is induced. She delivers a live 1.8kg female baby. She is admitted in the ICU post-delivery as she continues to have high BP and is finally discharged on the 5thpostnatal day with advice to follow up after 1 week. You are asked to help in preparing an audit of the Dept of OBG at the month end. This case is an example of?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Near-miss maternal mortality

 

  • This is an example of a near-miss maternal mortality
  • A near miss maternal mortality is defined as a pregnant or recently delivered woman who survived a complication during pregnancy, childbirth or 42 days after termination of pregnancy.
  • Criteria for maternal near miss: The WHO identifies 3 approaches

 

1. Disease Specific Criteria

 

  1. Severe preeclampsia/ eclampsia
  2. Severe hemorrhage
  3. Severe sepsis
  4. Uterine rupture

 

2. Management/ Intervention based

 

  1. Admission to ICU
  2. Obstetric hysterectomy
  3. Massive blood transfusion
  4. Intubation/ ventilation

 

3. Organ dysfunction-based criteria

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Options A. Maternal morbidity: This term refers to health complications experienced by a woman during pregnancy, childbirth, or the postpartum period that do not result in death. While the patient in the scenario did experience health complications, the term does not fully capture the severity of her condition.

 

Options B. Maternal mortality: This refers to the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management. The patient in the scenario survived, so this term does not apply.

 

Options C. Perinatal morbidity: This term pertains to health problems that occur in the fetus or newborn up to seven days post-delivery. Given the baby’s low birth weight, perinatal morbidity could apply to the newborn, but it does not describe the mother's condition.

 

Educational Objective: A near-miss maternal mortality, is a situation where a pregnant woman suffered from life-threatening complications but survived, during pregnancy, childbirth or 42 days after termination of pregnancy. thanks to timely and effective medical intervention. Near-miss cases are important for audits as they provide insights into the quality of care and help in designing strategies to prevent actual maternal deaths.

 

Ref: Evaluating the quality of care for severe pregnancy complications: The WHO near-miss approach for maternal health 2011
